g.text: populations. The goal is to provide guidelines for conservation decision-making based
on these data and the existing protected areas.
ve indicator endemic shrubby plants we aimto: (1) determine how genetic
diversity is spatially distributed in the Chihuahuan Desert; (2) establish the effect of
global climate change on their distribution based on predictions of future climate scenarios
for 2070; (3) understand how habitat ecological resistance among species might be affected
by future climate change; (4) identify the most vulnerable or resilient populations
and evaluate if they are located within protected areas; (5) make recommendations for

rst is the Mormon tea gymnosperm
a wind-pollinated species with rugged yellowish stems, dry seed cones and large seeds
), known as algerita or agarito, is a small to large shrub with gray or blue
ets with sharp spines, its yellow
Chihuahuan Sage or blue Texas ranger, is one of the most showy shrubs in the desert and
produces exuberant bright violet to purple small
plants are cultivated in nurseries and used as ornamentals in Texas and Arizona
of a monotypic genus endemic to the Chihuahuan Desert, with a shrubby or tree-like

Brandegee is the sole species of Setchellanthaceae, a
family endemic to the Chihuahuan Desert, and is receiving much interest because it
produces glucosinolates and belongs to the group of mustard plants. Its shrubs or small
trees have corky branches and showy lavender-violet
owers; populations are few and far
between and have been collected only in the north of the desert and in the Tehuac√°n

in their entire range. Protocols for extraction,
cation and sequencing including the DNA markers with their corresponding

). For the three remaining species we used previously published sequences
